Description: Two solid-cast elements in copper alloy, consisting of a mirror and a case; mirror of oblong, almost circular shape with a simple projecting tang to which was attached a missing handle; case flat with low rim, more circular in shape than mirror; heavily encrusted, corroded.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Mirrors had more than a pure domestic function. According to iconographic and archaeological evidences, they could be an object of cult, either offered as an ex-voto or part of the funerary equipment (Robinson 2010, 219-220). Mirrors and mirror covers featuring a plain disc with a raised ridge around the rim find good parallels at Olynthus (Robinson 1941, 171-172, pl. XXX). Robinson, D. M. 1941, Metal and Minor Miscellaneous Finds (Olynthus 10), Baltimore. Robinson, Z. 2010, ‘Living with Metals in Hellenistic Egypt – New Finds from Heraclion-Thonis’, in D. Robinson and A. Wilson (eds.), Alexandria and the North-West Delta, Oxford, 219–231.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (RA.08)
